{{Infobox Newspaper | name = Landlord Law & Multi-housing Report | type = [[Newsletter]] | format = [[Online journal]] | foundation = 1996 | owners = [[CD Publications]] | publisher = Mike Gerecht | editor = Robert Harris | headquarters = 8204 Fenton Street
[[Silver Spring, MD|Silver Spring]], [[Maryland|MD]] 20910
[[United States]] | website = [http://www.housinganddevelopment.com/ HousingandDevelopment.com] }} '''''Landlord Law & Multi-housing Report''''' is a news service (or [[newsletter]]) produced in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]] by [[CD Publications]]. It covers federal and state court decisions and [[Hud (housing)|HUD]] rulings on public, assisted, senior and disabled housing. ==History== CD Publications began publishing housing-related [[newsletters]] in 1961, starting with ''[[Housing Affairs Letter]]''. ''Managing Housing Letter'' began publication in 1978, and ''Landlord Law Report'' was added in 1996. In late 2006, ''MHL'' was merged with ''LLR'' to form ''Landlord Law & Multi-housing Report'', which still is referred to as ''LLR''. ===Current Coverage=== ''LLR'' carries synopses of recent federal and state court decisions on [[fair housing]], premises liability, rent/lease issues, eviction, handicapped accessibility, building security, and Section 8 tenants, plus summaries of HUD rulings. Each article also includes a short "lesson" to be learned from the outcome of the case. ===Expansion=== In 2007, ''LLR'' was changed to a web-based format and, along with CD Publications' other housing news services, was moved onto the web portal '''HousingandDevelopment.com'''. ==See also== *[[CD Housing Register]] *[[Community Development Digest]] *[[Housing Affairs Letter]] *[[Housing Market Report]] ==References== *"CD Publications' ''Landlord Law Report'' Newsletter." (1998-03-31). Found online at "Allbusiness.com (http://www.allbusiness.com/marketing/direct-marketing/730913-1.html)". ==External links== * [http://www.cdpublications.com/ CD Publications Home] * [http://www.housinganddevelopment.com/ HousingandDevelopment.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Landlord Law and Multi-housing Report}} [[Category:Publications established in 1996]] [[Category:Newsletters]] [[Category:Real estate in the United States]] [[Category:Real property law]]

'''Layle Lane''' (November 27, 1893 – February 2, 1976) was an [[African Americans|African American]] educator and civil rights activist.<ref name="NYPL">{{cite web|title=Layle Lane papers 1933-1951|url=http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20944|website=The New York Public Library - Archives and Manuscripts|publisher=The New York Public Library|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="UFT">{{cite web|title=United Federation of Teachers - Layle Lane|url=http://www.uft.org/who-we-are/history/layle-lane|website=United Federation of Teachers|publisher=|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="LAF">{{cite news|last1=Schierenbeck|first1=Jack|title=Lost and Found: The Incredible Life and Times of (Miss) Layle Lane|url=https://www.aft.org/sites/default/files/periodicals/LostandFound_JackSchierenbeck.pdf|accessdate=10 October 2017|work=American Educator|issue=Vol 24, No. 4, Winter 2000-2001|publisher=American Educator}}</ref>
==Life== Lane was born in [[Marietta, Georgia]] in 1893 to Reverend Calvin Lane and Alice Virginia Clark Lane.<ref name=NYPL /><ref name= LAF /> She was their fourth child. Her father was a [[Congregationalist]] minister and her mother was a teacher.<ref name=NYPL /><ref name=LAF /> Her family left Georgia after her father was threatened to be lynched.<ref name=UFT /> The family resettled in [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], and three years later in [[Vineland, New Jersey]].<ref name=NYPL /><ref name=UFT /><ref name=LAF /> In Vineland, Lane attended [[Vineland High School]], where she was the first black graduate of the school.<ref name=LAF /> Lane never married.<ref name=LAF /> In 1976, she died in [[Cuernavaca|Cuernavaca, Mexico]].<ref name="NYTO">{{cite web|title=Layle Lane, Rights Leader, Teachers’ Union Officer, 78|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1976/03/05/archives/layle-lane-rights-leader-teachers-union-officer-78.html|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=10 October 2017}}</ref>
==Education== Lane graduated from [[Howard University]] in 1916. After being unable to receive a job as a teacher in a New York public school, she returned to school earned a second undergraduate degree at [[Hunter College]]. She received her master's degree from [[Columbia University]].<ref name=NYTO /><ref name=UFT /><ref name=LAF />
==Career and activism== Lane became a high school teacher, teaching [[Social studies|social studies]] in a New York high school.<ref name=LAF /><ref name=UFT /> Lane was heavily involved in activism throughout her life, and participated in many protests for African American rights and workers' rights.<ref name=LAF /> She became an early member of the Teachers Union, and later the [[Teachers Guild]]. She served on the executive board of the Teacher's Guild.
Lane was elected the first black female [[American Federation of Teachers]] vice president. She ran five times as a candidate in the [[Socialist Party]] for public office. Three of those times were for Congress.<ref name=LAF /><ref name=UFT /> Lane served on the National Committee for Rural Schools.<ref name=NYTO /> She helped to plan and organize the [[March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom]] in 1941. Lane ran a summer camp on her Pennsylvania farm for impoverished black children from the inner-city.<ref name=LAF /><ref name=UFT /><ref name=NYTO /><ref name=NYPL />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://archives.nypl.org/scm/20944 The Layle Lane Papers at the New York Public Library] * [http://www.worldcat.org/title/citadelle-layle-lane-and-social-activism-in-twentieth-century-america/oclc/890625342 A book about Lane, "La citadelle : Layle Lane and social activism in twentieth-century America," on WorldCat] * [https://www.aft.org/sites/default/files/periodicals/LostandFound_JackSchierenbeck.pdf An article about Lane in a 2000 issue of American Educator]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lane, Layle}} [[Category:1893 births]] [[Category:1976 deaths]] [[Category:Hunter College alumni]] [[Category:People from Marietta, Georgia]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:People from Vineland, New Jersey]] [[Category:Vineland High School alumni]] [[Category:Howard University alumni]] [[Category:American Federation of Teachers people]] [[Category:Civil rights activists]] [[Category:American socialists]] [[Category:African-American activists]]

{{primary sources|date=June 2008}}
The '''Learning Disability Coalition''' is a group of fourteen organisations which campaigns to secure better funding for social care for people with [[learning disabilities]] in [[England]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mencap.org.uk/case.asp?id=133 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080622175147/http://www.mencap.org.uk/case.asp?id=133 |archivedate=2008-06-22 |df= }}</ref>
The Coalition was formed in May 2007.<ref>[http://www.arcuk.org.uk/999461/en/the+learning+disability+coalition.html]</ref> It believes that better funding from the [[UK Government]] is required to help people with learning disabilities to secure a full range of rights and opportunities. The LDC aims to provide a unified voice for people with learning disabilities to government and other key decision makers; to raise awareness of financial pressures on services, and achieve an evidence-based assessment of the long-term resource requirements for people with learning disabilities
==Members==
*The Foundation for People with Learning Disabilities *[[Mencap]] *People First *National Forum for People with Learning Difficulties *[[Sense-National Deafblind and Rubella Association|Sense]] *[[Turning Point (charity)|Turning Point]] *Down’s Syndrome Association *[[United Response]] *BILD (British Institute of Learning Disabilities) *[[ARC Association for Real Change]] *[[National Autistic Society]] *Real Life Options *National Family Carer Network *Voyage *The Hesley Group
==Protect the Frontline==
In 2010 the LDC launched its ‘Protect the Frontline’ campaign which is calling on politicians to keep to their promises and protect frontline services for people with a learning disability. As part of the campaign, the LDC produced ‘Stories from the Frontline’,<ref>(http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/download/PFL_report_32pp_web.pdf)</ref> which included a series of diaries by people with a learning disability. These diaries helped to show the importance of frontline social care and the difference that it makes to their lives and the lives of their families. The LDC has been monitoring cuts to social care through its cutswatch feature,<ref>(http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/cutswatch.asp)</ref> and since the announcement of the [[Comprehensive Spending Review]], has been calling on local councillors <ref>(http://e-activist.com/ea-campaign/clientcampaign.do?ea.client.id=78&ea.campaign.id=8778&ea.tracking.id=LDCweb)</ref> to ensure that social care spending is protected at a local level.
==Management==
The Coalition's Director is Anthea Sully and its Co-Chairs are Andrew Lee, Director of People First and Mark Goldring, Chief Executive of Mencap.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081209105713/http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/download/Case_for_Real_Change.pdf The Case for Real Change] - a report setting out the Coalition's views on the future of social care. * [http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/download/CEDR_November.pdf Estimating Future Need for Adult Social Care Services for People with Learning Disabilities in England] - a report published by Mencap and the Centre for Disability Research at Lancaster University which presents the latest estimates for future prevalence of learning disability. * [http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk Learning Disability Coalition website] * [http://www.facebook.com/LearningDisabilityCoalition Learning Disability Coalition Facebook page] * [http://www.lga.gov.uk/lga/core/page.do?pageId=41543 LGA response to Learning Disability Coalition figures] * [http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/download/People_with_Learning%20Disabilities_in_England.pdf People with Learning Disabilities in England] - a report published by Mencap, the Learning Disability Coalition and the Centre for Disability Research at Lancaster University * [http://www.learningdisabilitycoalition.org.uk/download/Tell_it_like_it_is.pdf Tell It Like It Is] A report published by the Learning Disability Coalition showing the extent of cuts to services for people with a learning disability
[[Category:Disability rights organizations]] [[Category:Learning disabilities]] [[Category:Disability organisations based in the United Kingdom]]

This article contains a list of [[Corruption in Ghana|corruption case in Ghana]]. * [[Ghana SSNIT software scandal|SSNIT software scandal]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/dossier.php?ID=674|title=DOSSIER: SSNIT software procurement scandal|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/April-18th/ssnit-software-saga-ernest-thompson-others-to-face-prosecution.php|title=SSNIT software saga: Ernest Thompson, others to face prosecution|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.peacefmonline.com/pages/local/news/201804/349886.php|title=$72m SSNIT Saga: Four Officials Charged With Financial Loss|last=Online|first=Peace FM|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/February-23rd/eoco-indicts-ssnit-officials-over-controversial-72m-software-contract.php|title=EOCO indicts SSNIT officials over controversial $72m software contract|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> * [[National Health Insurance Scheme (Ghana)#Controversies|NHIS scandal]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://myxyzonline.com/general/nhis-in-400k-contract-scandal/|title=NHIS In 400K Contract Scandal|date=2018-05-22|work=myxyzonline|access-date=2018-06-02|language=en}}</ref> * GYEEDA saga<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/artikel.php?ID=338492|title=GYEEDA Saga: Indicted companies fail to refund State money|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tv3network.com/business/gh-200-million-recovered-from-companies-in-gyeeda-scandal|title=GH₵200 million recovered from companies in GYEEDA scandal|last=Effah|first=Steven|website=tv3network.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citifmonline.com/2018/02/23/court-rules-on-gyeeda-scandal-case-today/|title=Court rules on 'GYEEDA' scandal case today - citifmonline.com|date=2018-02-23|work=citifmonline.com|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> * BOST contaminated fuel scandal<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/07/05/govts-handling-of-bost-scandal-insulting-minority/|title=Gov't's handling of BOST scandal insulting - Minority - citifmonline.com|date=2017-07-05|work=citifmonline.com|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thenewstateman.com/single-post/2017/12/18/BOST-MD-In-GH-2-Million-Corruption-Scandal|title=TheNewStateman {{!}} Ghana|website=TheNewStateman {{!}} Ghana|language=en|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/07/06/bost-npa-others-sued-over-contaminated-fuel-saga/|title=BOST, NPA, others sued over contaminated fuel saga - citifmonline.com|date=2017-07-06|work=citifmonline.com|access-date=2018-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ghanaguardian.com/contaminated-fuel-scandal-ministerial-ctee-not-trustworthy-bost-workers|title=Contaminated fuel scandal: Ministerial C’tee not trustworthy – BOST workers|website=The Ghana Guardian News|language=en|access-date=2018-06-16}}</ref> *GFA 2018 scandal<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://citinewsroom.com/2018/05/24/more-gfa-officials-caught-in-anas-documentary/|title=More GFA officials caught in Anas' documentary|date=2018-05-24|work=Citi Newsroom|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/June-16th/number-12-anas-hands-nyantakyi-evidence-to-police.php|title=Number 12: Anas hands ‘Nyantakyi evidence’ to police|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/June-6th/number-12-ghanaians-ecstatic-as-anas-documentary-premiers-today.php|title='Number 12': Ghanaians ecstatic as Anas’ documentary premieres today|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref> *Ghana Judiciary Scandal<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Judicial-scandal-21-judges-sacked-399177|title=Judicial scandal: 21 judges sacked|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref> *Ghana EC Scandal<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/07/10/ec-ghc480000-scandal-documents-reveal-finance-director-wasnt-at-post/|title=EC GHc480,000 scandal: Documents reveal Finance Director wasn't at post - citifmonline.com|date=2017-07-10|work=citifmonline.com|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/politics/2017/July-25th/president-akufo-addo-under-pressure-to-probe-ec-chaos.php|title=Akufo-Addo under pressure to probe EC chaos|date=2017-07-25|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://dailyguideafrica.com/scandal-ec-rot-exposed/|title=Scandal At EC: More Rot Exposed! - Daily Guide Africa|website=dailyguideafrica.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref> *Tema Port Scandal<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/NewsArchive/Corruption-at-Tema-Port-Government-loses-US-8-3m-monthly-527837|title=Corruption at Tema Port: Government loses US$ 8.3m monthly|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulse.com.gh/news/business/ghana-ports-corruption-at-the-ports-is-unbearable-bawumiah-id6706562.html|title=Ghana Ports: Corruption at the Ports is unbearable - Bawumiah|last=Frimpong|first=Desmond|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://3news.com/corruption-at-tema-harbour-a-cartel-get-killed-or-get-sacked-carl-wilson/|title=Corruption at Tema Harbour a cartel; get killed or get sacked – Carl Wilson - 3newsgh|date=2016-08-23|work=3newsgh|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref> *Stephen Opuni Cocoa Board Scandal<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/March-14th/former-cocobod-boss-charged-with-27-counts-of-causing-financial-loss.php|title=Former COCOBOD Boss charged with 27 counts of causing financial loss|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myjoyonline.com/news/2018/March-16th/the-opuni-story-how-it-started-and-where-we-are-so-far.php|title=The Opuni story: How it started and where we are so far|access-date=2018-06-30|language=en-US}}</ref> *
==See also== *2015 Ghana Judiciary scandal

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = M. Rony Francois |image = |imagesize = 150px |caption = |office = [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Director of the Georgia Division of Public Health]] |governor = [[Sonny Perdue]]
[[Nathan Deal]] |term_start = 2010 |term_end = 2015 |predecessor = |successor = |office2 = [[Florida Department of Health|Secretary of the Florida Department of Health]] |governor2 = [[Jeb Bush]] |term_start2 = September 19, 2005 |term_end2 = January 2, 2007 |predecessor2= |successor2 = [[Ana Viamonte Ros]] |birth_date = |birth_place = [[Port-au-Prince, Haiti|Port-au-Prince]], [[Haiti]] |death_date = |death_place = |religion = |profession = Doctor, health administrator, professor |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |alma_mater = [[University of Central Florida]]
[[University of South Florida]] |spouse = |footnotes = |website = }} '''M. Rony Francois''' is an [[United States|American]] [[Medical doctor|doctor]], [[Health administration|health administrator]], and [[Professor|academic professor]]. He is currently the Director of the Georgia Division of Public Health.{{cite news |url=http://www.ajc.com/news/lifestyles/health/francois-named-new-director-of-public-health/nQb8D/ |title=Francois named new director of public health |date=2010-01-29 |accessdate=2013-01-12 |work=The Atlanta Journal Constitution}} He previously served as Secretary of the [[Florida Department of Health]] under then [[Florida Governor]] [[Jeb Bush]] from 2005 to 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.gainesville.com/article/20070118/LOCAL/701180317?p=1&tc=pg |title=Crist selects Florida's first surgeon general |date=2007-01-18 |accessdate=2013-01-12 |work=The Gainesville Sun}}{{cite web |url=http://www.doh.state.fl.us/environment/newsroom/press_releases/12.01.05HWinterCarbon.pdf |title=DOH WARNS OF THE DANGERS OF CARBON MONOXIDE EXPOSURE DURING WINTER |publisher=Florida Department of Health |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927163931/http://www.doh.state.fl.us/environment/newsroom/press_releases/12.01.05HWinterCarbon.pdf |archivedate=2011-09-27 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.jonesbahamas.com/pdf.php?a%3D9597 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100924144515/http://jonesbahamas.com/pdf.php?a=9597 |archivedate=2010-09-24 |df= }} Florida Secretary Of Health Dr. M. Rony Francois Tours The Bahamas HIV/ AIDS Center Francois is an alumnus of the [[University of Central Florida]] and the [[University of South Florida]]. He earned his bachelor's degree and master's degree from UCF, where he was also a star on the [[UCF Knights men's soccer|Knights soccer team]], and he graduated with his [[medical degree]] from South Florida in 1994.{{cite web |url=http://health.usf.edu/publicaffairs/newsreleases/news+release+09+14+05+francois.htm |title=USF Public Health Professor named Florida Secretary of Health |date=2005-09-10 |accessdate=2013-01-12 |work=University of South Florida}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Francois, M. Rony}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Health officials]] [[Category:University of Central Florida alumni]] [[Category:University of South Florida alumni]] [[Category:Haitian emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American politicians of Haitian descent]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) Republicans]] {{US-poli-bio-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Marietta Peabody Tree | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Marietta Endicott Peabody | birth_date = {{Birth date|1917|04|17}} | birth_place = [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1991|08|15|1917|04|17}} | death_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = [[St. Timothy's School]] | alma_mater = [[University of Pennsylvania]] | occupation = Socialite, political supporter | years_active = | known_for = | spouse = [[Desmond Fitzgerald (CIA officer)|Desmond FitzGerald]] (1939–1947)
[[Ronald Tree]] (1947–1976) | partner = | children = [[Frances FitzGerald (journalist)|Frances FitzGerald]]
[[Penelope Tree]] | parents = [[Malcolm E. Peabody|Malcolm Endicott Peabody]]
Mary Elizabeth Parkman | relatives = [[Endicott Peabody (educator)|Rev. Endicott Peabody]] (grandfather)
[[Endicott Peabody]] (brother){{cite news|last=Palumbo|first=Mary Jo|title=Marietta Tree, at 74, longtime public servant|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/69022531.html?dids=69022531:69022531&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT|accessdate=2 December 2011|newspaper=Boston Herald|date=August 17, 1991}} }} '''Marietta Peabody Tree''' (April 17, 1917 – August 15, 1991) was an American [[socialite]] and political supporter, who represented the United States on the [[United Nations Commission on Human Rights]], appointed under the administration of [[John F. Kennedy]]. ==Early life== '''Marietta Endicott Peabody''' was the only daughter of Malcolm Endicott Peabody, the rector of Grace Episcopal Church in [[Lawrence, Massachusetts]], and Mary Elizabeth Parkman. Her grandfather [[Endicott Peabody (educator)|Rev. Endicott Peabody]] was founder and first headmaster of [[Groton School]] where her four brothers Endicott, Samuel, George, and Malcolm were educated.{{ cite web|url=http://nj.essortment.com/humansrightsco_rwkz.htm |title=Human Rights Commission & Marietta Peabody Tree biography |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080905100314/http://nj.essortment.com/humansrightsco_rwkz.htm |archivedate=2008-09-05 |df= }} Although born into an old New England family, Tree's parents were strictly middle-class, and were among the old-line Yankees and [[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopalians]] in what was fast becoming the [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholic]] stronghold of Lawrence. Tree's mother Mary was an extensive charity worker, and encouraged her daughter to get involved with the community. Tree attended [[St. Timothy's School]], where she excelled in athletics above studies. An effervescent, leggy blonde, she was an accomplished flirt and irresistible to men from an early age.{{cite magazine |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n1_v30/ai_20239566 |title=No Regrets: The Life of Marietta Tree. - book reviews |magazine=Washington Monthly |first=Sandra |last=McElwaine |year=1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080228052221/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n1_v30/ai_20239566 |archivedate=2008-02-28}} {{cite magazine |title=[Page 2] |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n1_v30/ai_20239566/pg_2 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090624221042/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1316/is_n1_v30/ai_20239566/pg_2/ |archivedate=2009-06-24 |deadurl=yes }} She undertook a grand tour of [[Europe]] and [[finishing school]] in [[Florence]] upon graduation to avoid college.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/11/09/reviews/971109.09brubact.html | work=The New York Times | title=Running Around in High Circles}} When asked to predict her own future, she wrote down: "Parties, people, and politics." Her father insisted that she, unlike many society girls of the time, attend college, and she enrolled at the [[University of Pennsylvania]] in 1936. Although she withdrew from the Class of 1940, reflecting the era's skepticism of higher education for women,{{cite web|url=http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/women/quote5.html |title=Quotations, 1940-1949, from Women at Penn, University of Pennsylvania Archives}} in later interviews she would exclaim: "I'll never stop being grateful to my father for forcing me to go to college. It changed my life." In 1964 she was presented with an honorary [[Doctor of Laws]] degree, and in 1971 with an honorary [[Bachelor of Arts]]. She is also an honorary member of [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] Sorority. ==Desmond FitzGerald== During college, Marietta was courted by [[Harvard]] law graduate and [[New York City]] [[lawyer]] [[Desmond Fitzgerald (CIA officer)|Desmond FitzGerald]]. The couple married on September 2, 1939, and Marietta gave birth to a daughter [[Frances FitzGerald (journalist)|Frances FitzGerald]], who later became a noted [[journalist]] and [[historian]]. Marietta began a career as a fact checker despite having no college degree and no prior journalistic experience, and latterly writer for ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine. At night she partied with the [[Astor family|Astors]], [[William S. Paley|Paleys]], and [[Warburg family|Warburgs]], describing these years as "a fever of happiness." Her ardent liberal [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] views clashed with those of her [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] husband and created tensions in the marriage. After America entered the [[World War II|Second World War]] in December 1941, Marietta accepted a post as part of the American delegation assisting the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]]. When Desmond left New York to fulfill a role in the war effort, Marietta started a passionate and intense affair with the film director [[John Huston]]. Rumors, ones often perpetuated by Tree's daughters and friends, liked to paint Marietta as "the only woman Huston ever truly loved." ==Ronald Tree== Although contemplating marriage with Huston, Marietta and FitzGerald were invited to [[Barbados]] by a colleague from the British Ministry of Information. [[Ronald Tree]], whose mother was the daughter of retail magnate [[Marshall Field]], was then a dollar billionaire; he himself was then [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Harborough (UK Parliament constituency)|Harborough]], [[Leicestershire]] and friend of [[Winston Churchill]]. Although both were married, Marietta and Tree began an affair. Although he was [[bisexual]] and twenty years older than Marietta, Tree and Peabody divorced their respective partners at the end of World War II and married on July 26, 1947. Marietta moved into Tree's home, [[Ditchley|Ditchley Park]], but found herself bored with English country life. Tree and most of his friends were [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservatives]], and Democrat Marietta again found herself politically isolated. Their daughter [[Penelope Tree|Penelope]] was born in 1949. For the first time in his life short of money, Ronald Tree sold Ditchley and agreed to return to [[New York City]] with Marietta, her daughter Frances Fitzgerald and their own daughter, future '60s fashion model Penelope Tree,{{cite web |title=Notable Kin - Surprising Connections #s 6 and 7: Boston Cousins of Queen Victoria and Yankee Ancestors of Mrs. Thomas Philip “Tip” O’Neill, Jr. |author=Gary Boyd Roberts |url=http://www.newenglandancestors.org/education/articles/NEXUS/Nexus_10.4.8.asp |publisher=New England Historic Genealogical Society |website=NewEnglandAncestors.org |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927032452/http://www.newenglandancestors.org/education/articles/NEXUS/Nexus_10.4.8.asp |archive-date=2007-09-27}} and his butler Collins.{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,876373,00.html?iid=chix-sphere | work=Time | title=Diplomacy: Come to the Party | date=1964-11-06}} ==Politics and Adlai Stevenson== Marietta Tree immediately joined the Lexington Democratic Club, and two years later was elected the county chairwoman. She was elected to the Democratic State Committee in 1954. In 1952, Tree became involved in the Presidential election campaign of [[Adlai Stevenson II|Adlai Stevenson]]. After his defeat, the two became constant companions and lovers, but Ronald Tree was unfazed and even invited Stevenson to the couple's homes in New York, [[Barbados]] and London.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Marietta and Stevenson developed code names for each other – Mr. and Mrs. Johnson, and Mr. and Mrs. Richardson – and arranged trysts at various friends' houses that they considered safe.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} Tree was part of Stevenson's unsuccessful 1956 Presidential campaign, and upon his return to a legal career the pair continued their affair but became slightly more distant. Stevenson also took other lovers, keeping Marietta on edge, frequently disclosing his encounters by stockpiling in a drawer by his bed a number of poems and meditations of love that he would send and receive from various women. This encouraged Tree's earlier lover, the film director John Huston, who even gave her a role in his 1960 movie ''[[The Misfits (film)|The Misfits]]''. However, she was devoted to Stevenson, and although she refused to divorce Tree, she gladly accepted [[John F. Kennedy]]'s offer of becoming the [[United States Representative to the United Nations Commission on Human Rights]], aptly appointed under Stevenson as the head of the American delegation. She served in this position from 1961 to 1964. On July 14, 1965, Tree and Stevenson were walking in [[London]] when he suffered a [[heart attack]], and later died at [[St George's Hospital]]. That night in her diary, she wrote: "Adlai is dead. We were together." ==Later life== Ronald and Marietta became virtually estranged. Ronald Tree died of a stroke on July 14, 1976, in London, while Marietta was in New York. Ronald Tree left Marietta with little money, and she was forced to sell much of the couple's property to remain financially stable. She started an affair with [[England|English]] [[architect]] [[Richard Llewelyn-Davies]], and financed the married man's business expansion into the United States. But Davies died suddenly, and Tree was forced to cover some of the estate's debts. Tree through her connections was able to obtain some well paid directorships, including the boards of [[CBS]], [[Pan Am]], and [[Lend Lease Corporation]] of Australia. She also served as women's trustee on the board of the [[University of Pennsylvania]].[http://www.archives.upenn.edu/histy/features/women/trustees.html Penn's Women Trustees, University of Pennsylvania Archives] These positions and incomes enabled her to not only support herself, but resist calls from her later publishing and political community lovers to write her memoirs, including lover Eben Pyne. She also served on the [[The Metropolitan Museum of Art Centennial|Metropolitan Museum of Art’s 100th Anniversary]] Committee.[http://libmma.org/digital_files/archives/Trescher_Centennial_records_b18234550.pdf Finding aid for the George Trescher records related to The Metropolitan Museum of Art Centennial, 1949, 1960-1971 (bulk 1967-1970)]. [[The Metropolitan Museum of Art]]. Retrieved 6 August 2014. In 1987 she appeared in the [[Danny Huston]] film ''[[Mr. North]]'', released about a month before John Huston died of [[emphysema]] on August 28, 1987. Her friends in the 1980s included [[Donald Trump]], [[Charles Wrightsman]] (who in 1986 bought the [[Lorenzo Lotto]] artwork ''[[Venus and Cupid (Lotto)|Venus and Cupid]]'' in her honour for the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]);[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/ho/08/eustn/hod_1986.138.htm Lorenzo Lotto: Venus and Cupid (1986.138) | Works of Art | Timeline of Art History | The Metropolitan Museum of Art] and [[Ronald Reagan|President Ronald]] and [[Nancy Reagan]], the latter of whom she was criticized for in the Democratic party, which she worked for until 1990 when she was diagnosed with [[breast cancer]]. ==Death== Tree fought breast cancer hard, including undertaking a double [[mastectomy]], and told her friends she was suffering from [[influenza]]. Tree died on August 15, 1991, at her home in New York. Her ashes were buried by her daughters. ==Character== Tree was brought up in a strict household, whose requirements she transferred to her own daughters: they never had dolls when children. [[Isaiah Berlin]] characterized her political standing as, "a progressive, liberal figure who was mixed up with a lot of naive left-wing sympathizers." Like her contemporary [[Pamela Harriman]], Marietta attained through men what women of her time were forbidden to attain for themselves. As the [[feminist]] movement gained momentum in the 1960s, Marietta refused to support its cause, and in 1967 she angered her fellow female delegates to the New York state constitutional convention, by refusing to sign three resolutions pertaining to women's rights.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/11/09/reviews/971109.09brubact.html |title=Running Around in High Circles |date=November 9, 1997 |author=Holly Bruback |work=The New York Times |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140910132123/http://www.nytimes.com/books/97/11/09/reviews/971109.09brubact.html |archive-date=2014-09-10 |department=Books }} ==References== *Seebohm, Caroline - ''No Regrets: The Life of Marietta Tree.'' Pub: Simon & Schuster, 1998 {{ISBN|0-684-81008-5}} == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|id=0871684|name=Marietta Tree}} *[http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:RAD.SCHL:sch00614 Marietta Tree Papers] at the [[Schlesinger Library]], Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tree, Marietta Peabody}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1991 deaths]] [[Category:American Episcopalians]] [[Category:American expatriates in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American socialites]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in New York (state)]] [[Category:Deaths from breast cancer]] [[Category:New York (state) Democrats]] [[Category:People from Lawrence, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Time (magazine) people]] [[Category:Representatives of the United States to the United Nations Human Rights Council]] [[Category:Women ambassadors]] [[Category:American women diplomats]]

page.title: Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development (Ghana)

revision.comment: [[WP:GenFixes]] on; 3+ incoming mainspace links, removed orphan tag using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
The '''Ministry of [[Fishery|Fisheries]] and Aquaculture Development''' (MOFAD) is a ministry in the [[Ghana]]ian government that concentrates on carrying out development interventions to move the fisheries sector and the industry to contribute efficiently to the overall development of the [[Ghanaian people|Ghanaian]] [[economy]]. This forms part of the "2014-2017 Sector Medium Term Development Plan" (SMTDP).
The purpose serves as a sector "development compass" that directs or guides the operations of the Ministry, the [[private sector]] (fisheries industry players), and putting together agencies in the development of the fisheries sector. The ultimate goal of this Plan is to "consolidate the sector gains made' for the period 2010-2013, and to fast track the contribution of the fisheries sector to national development and growth through the implementation of target-specific and growth inducing strategies and interpositions".<ref name=":0" /> It is also a "medium term road map" that is directed at guiding [[Government]] investment and Development Partner support to revamp the fisheries sector for 2014-2017 and the years ahead.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/about-mofad/mofad-at-a-glance/|title=MoFAD At-a-glance – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
{{Infobox government agency | name = Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development (MOFAD) | seal = | logo = | formed = [[Government of Ghana]] | jurisdiction = [[Government of Ghana]] | headquarters = {{Flagicon|Ghana}} [[Accra|Accra, Ghana]] | employees = | budget = | chief1_name = [[Elizabeth Afoley Quaye]] | chief1_position = Minister | chief2_name = | chief2_position = | chief3_name = | chief3_position = | chief4_name = | chief4_position = | chief5_name = | chief5_position = | chief6_name = | chief6_position = | chief7_name = | chief7_position = | chief8_name = | chief8_position = | chief9_name = | chief9_position = | parent_department = | website = http://www.mofad.gov.gh/ }}
== Goals and Policy of the Ministry == {{Politics of Ghana}} The destination of MOFAD is promotion of accelerated Fisheries Sector Development as a viable economic segment that will conduce to the total development of the economy of [[Ghana]] in line with Medium to Long term National Development Policy Frameworks of the [[country]].
The main objective of the Plan stated above  is to enhance operational effectiveness and efficiency of MOFAD and all Plan implementing partners towards the achievement of stated sector policy objectives and time-bound targets, output and outcomes of the fisheries sector that are in line with the total medium term [[evolution]] Goals and policy objectives of the Ghana Shared Growth and Development Agenda (GSGDA II).
The ideas gained from the goals of the Ministry derived its policy base from the thematic focus areas and broad policy objectives and strategies of (GSGDA II) that are relevant to the mandate and functions of MOFAD.<ref name=":0" />
== Leadership == MoFAD consists of several departments and agencies. In total, the Ministry is headed by a Sector Minister, and each agency or department has a director as an official head.In view of this, the Fisheries Commission is the implementing agency of the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development (MoFAD) and is headed by the Director of the Fisheries Commission.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/about-mofad/leadership/|title=Leadership – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/agencies/fisheries-commission/fisheries-commission-at-a-glance/|title=Fisheries Commission At-a-glance – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/agencies/fisheries-commission/director-of-fisheries-commission/|title=Director of Fisheries Commission – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== Divisions of Fisheries Commission == The Fisheries Commission has five (5) active divisions:
'''A.'''      Marine Fisheries Management Division (MFMD)
'''B.'''       Inland Fisheries Management Division (IFMD)
'''C.'''       Fisheries Scientiﬁc Survey Division (FSSD)
'''D.'''      Monitoring, Control, and Surveillance Division (MCSD)
'''E.'''       Operations and Administration Divisions (OAD)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/agencies/fisheries-commission/divisions-of-fisheries-commission/|title=Divisions of Fisheries Commission – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== Units of Fisheries Commission == The Commission has four (4) operational units:
A.   Fish Health Unit (FHU)
B.    Monitoring and Evaluation Unit (MEU)
C.    Post-Harvest Unit (PHU)
D.   Projects Unit (PU)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/agencies/fisheries-commission/units-of-fisheries-commission/|title=Units of Fisheries Commission – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== National Premix Secretariat == The National Premix Committee (NPC) was constituted by the government of Ghana in July 2009 to oversee the administration and distribution of premix fuel, a hugely subsidised [[petroleum]] product in the country.
Landing Beach Committees (LBCs) were established at the various landing beaches to empower the [[Fisherman|fishermen]] to operate premix fuel stations at the landing beaches. Each LBC was required to choose an Oil Marketing Company to supply them with premix fuel. Proceeds from the sale of premix fuel at the landing beaches are to be used in developing the fishing communities in the country.
A National Premix Secretariat (NPS) was formed to service the NPC. The allotment and distribution of premix fuel is undertaken by the NPS. Requests made weekly for the distribution of premix fuel are sent to the Tema Oil Reﬁnery (TOR). TOR refines and loads the product into tankers of the assigned Oil Marketing Companies (OMCs) for distribution to the various Landing Beach Committees.
=== Mandate ===
The NPC’s responsibility is to supervise the efficient and effective administration and distribution of premix fuel. Since premix fuel is highly subsidized by the government, the NPC makes sure that monitoring is enforced to avoid diversion or inappropriate distribution. The NPC are tasked to ensure that the proceeds from the sale of premix fuel are being used to develop the fishing communities in the country. Diverse developmental projects were undertaken by majority of the LBCs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/agencies/national-premix-secretariat/|title=National Premix Secretariat – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== Directorates == The following are directorates of the Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development (MoFAD) with each directorate headed by a director. *   Internal Audit *   Finance and Administration *   Human Resource *   Research, Statistics, and Information Management (RSIM) *   Policy Planning, Monitoring, and Evaluation (PPMED)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/about-mofad/departments/|title=Directorates – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
==Collaborating MDAs (Ministries, Departments and Agencies) and Institutions == MoFAD and its agencies (the Fisheries Commission and the National Premix Secretariat) work hand in hand with over 80% of the Ministries in Ghana and other entities in order to develop a reliable, disciplined, manageable, and sustainable fisheries sector for Ghanaian's.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/about-mofad/collaborating-mdas-and-institutions/|title=Collaborating MDAs and Institutions – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== Laws and Regulations == The Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development (MOFAD) was formed under the 1992 Constitution of the republic of Ghana and backed by the Laws of the Land.It takes into consideration the “FISHERIES (AMENDMENT) REGULATIONS , 2015 (L.I. 2217)”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mofad.gov.gh/publications/laws-and-regulations/|title=Laws and Regulations – Ministry of Fisheries and Aquaculture Development|website=www.mofad.gov.gh|language=en-US|access-date=2017-11-30}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Fishing in Ghana]] *[[Economy of Ghana]] *[[Government of Ghana]] *[[Ministry of Food and Agriculture (Ghana)|Ministry of Food and Agriculture]]
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://www.tor.com.gh/ Tema Oil Refinery(TOR)] * [http://mofa.gov.gh/site/ Ministry of Food and Agriculture]
